#Text=Fred Bass
#Text=For the owner of Strand Bookstore , see Fred Bass ( businessman ) .
#Text=Fred
#Text=Bass
#Text=is a former city councillor , environmentalist and a preventive medicine physician in Vancouver , British Columbia , Canada .
#Text=Background
#Text=Bass was born in New York City , attended Antioch College , Case-Western Reserve Medical School , Harvard , and Johns Hopkins .
#Text=He served as a preventive medicine officer in the US Army 's 7th Infantry Division in Korea and Fort Monmouth , New Jersey .
#Text=After his military service , he was a tuberculosis control officer for the New Jersey Department of Health and unit medical health officer .

#Text=He earned a master 's degree in epidemiology at the Harvard School of Public Health and a Doctor of Science at Johns Hopkins , writing a thesis on medical care use attributable to cigarette smoking .
#Text=He taught at the University of Pennsylvania and came to the Vancouver Health Department in 1975 .
#Text=There , in 1982 , he became director of health promotion .
#Text=In 1989 , he founded the BC Doctors Stop-Smoking Program to help doctors help their patients stop smoking .
#Text=He helped to form the Society for Clinical Preventive Care in 1997 , which has a mission to implement proven clinical preventive measures .
#Text=In 2001 he was awarded a Senior ( life ) Membership in the Canadian Medical Association for his extensive work in tobacco control .
#Text=He continues in 2007 to serve as the medical director of the Society for Clinical Preventive Health Care .
#Text=Early involvement with Vancouver politics
#Text=In 1989 – 90 , Bass served on Vancouver 's Clouds of Change Task Force which addressed the issues of global climate change .

#Text=Bass , concerned about global warming , entered electoral politics in 1996 as a candidate for Vancouver 's civic Green Party under the leadership of Stuart Parker but was defeated by a wide margin .

#Text=However , the increased share of the vote won by the Greens and of a new populist party called VOICE resulted in a total rout for the city 's leftist forces in which every single candidate who was not a member of the Non-Partisan Association was defeated .

#Text=Despite being the Greens ' second-best vote-getter in the 1996 election ( second only to the party 's provincial leader Stuart Parker ) , Bass was defeated when he sought renomination by the Greens in 1999 .

#Text=With the support of the Greens ' executive and provincial leadership , he sought and won the nomination of the Coalition of Progressive Electors ( COPE ) , the party with which the Greens had just inked a coalition agreement .
#Text=Elected city councillor
#Text=Bass was first elected to city council in 1999 as a member of COPE , and topped the polls when re-elected in 2002 with 70,525 votes .
#Text=His political priorities were action on the environment and transit .
#Text=Bass was outspoken in his opposition to the expansion of gambling and to excessive expenditures for rapid transit by a faction of his party under the leadership of Mayor Larry Campbell .
#Text=In 2003 – 2005 , three COPE councillors and the mayor split from the party to form Vision Vancouver .
#Text=Bass and councillors Tim Louis , David Cadman , Anne Roberts and Ellen Woodsworth remained in COPE .
#Text=Bass was not re-elected in the 2005 election , finishing 12th overall with 48,248 votes .

#Text=Bass introduced a controversial motion in 2005 to widen the sidewalks on the Burrard Bridge to encourage cyclists and pedestrians , but first do a minimal-cost trial of using one lane in each direction for bicycles , reserving the existing sidewalk for pedestrians , despite the failure of a similar experiment in 1996 .
#Text=The sidewalk-widening was slated to cost $ 13 million if the $ 2 million trial failed .
#Text=Some cyclists applauded the move , though other users of the current bridge sidewalks questioned whether any changes were necessary .
#Text=Concerns about motorist rage did not deter Bass , who stated " Motorists called for my head long ago and my head is still on my neck .
